bug.short_desc: [compiler][null] Restore behaviour of null defaults for binary types

long_desc.thetext:
Reading @NonNullByDefault on binary types was actually fixed by commit 4817a4bde9db799e7a793068d64037f59bfa521f
I'll take a look what is broken here.

Created attachment 211294 Fixes for annotation on binary package
Actually for @NonNullByDefault on a binary type I cannot reproduce any problem. Are you sure project Y had null annotation support enabled?
However, I could spot some issues with @NonNullByDefault on a binary package-info. Those issues are fixed by the attached patch. Now X can even be read from a jar and still type level and package level defaults are respected.
Let me know if you still see a problem that's not covered by the patch.

(In reply to comment #1) > Reading @NonNullByDefault on binary types was actually fixed by commit > 4817a4bde9db799e7a793068d64037f59bfa521f > > I'll take a look what is broken here.
I could see that without the patch in comment#2, the defaults work when applied at method or class level. If applied at package level or at enclosing class level, it doesn't.

(In reply to comment #2) > Created attachment 211294 [details] > Fixes for annotation on binary package > > Actually for @NonNullByDefault on a binary type I cannot reproduce any problem. > Are you sure project Y had null annotation support enabled? Yes, the problem is only with package-info.java or enclosing types.
Patch looks good, but a small comment: The org.eclipse.jdt.internal.compiler.lookup.BinaryTypeBinding.scanTypeForNullDefaultAnnotation(IBinaryType) method is called multiple times for package-info.java for each class in the package. This can be avoided by checking for the defaultNullness field in the beginning, and skipping the method if it already is set.
Also, maybe the method isViewedAsDeprecated can be renamed to reflect the fact that it is also used to collect the null defaults?

The patch still does not deal with @NonNullByDefault annotations on enclosing types. Also, I think org.eclipse.jdt.internal.compiler.lookup.LookupEnvironment.createBinaryTypeFrom(IBinaryType, PackageBinding, boolean, AccessRestriction) is a better place to scan for default annotations maybe

Created attachment 211317 alternate patch
Here's the approach that I suggested. This works whether the annotation is in package-info or on an enclosing type.
However, one problem with both above patches is: Since we're using the lookup environment of the current project to get the annotation name, this will only work when the annotation type used for @NonNullByDefault in both current project and that being referenced via a JAR is the same. I'm at a loss to understand how to handle this situation. Stephan, do you have any ideas? Also, can we add regression tests for this bug?

(In reply to comment #6) > I'm at a loss to understand how to handle this situation. Stephan, do you have > any ideas? Sorry for bringing this up again. This has been discussed in the past a few times already. bug 365387 comment 53 has the final verdict on this point.

Created attachment 211326 alternate patch + tests
Added regression tests too

(In reply to comment #8)
A few remarks on the patch:
(1) The value of CharOperation.equals(binaryBinding.sourceName(), TypeConstants.PACKAGE_INFO_NAME) could be cached inside scanTypeForNullDefaultAnnotation(), a nicely named local variable would improve readability :)
(2) Thanks for handling annotations on enclosing types, which my patch missed. However, what happens if binaryBinding.enclosingType is an UnresolvedReferenceBinding? I'm afraid we'd need to use binaryBinding.enclosingType() which spoils lazy resolving for projects that use null annotations. Or is that scenario unreachable in the first place?
(3) Why is a loop over enclosingType() needed? Can't we assume the directly enclosing has all necessary information? I'm not sure.
(4) Lookup of package-info inside scanTypeForNullDefaultAnnotation() can actually be avoided if the type has a default annotation. Why not defer until before the very final switch in this method?
Some more notes which don't require any action:
(a) The use of NULL_UNSPECIFIED_BY_DEFAULT implies that we don't consider package nesting. This is OK for now, but would need to be changed if one day we enable @NonNullByDefault on a package to also affect "sub-packages".
(b) I'm not sure what's the advantage of pulling the call to scanTypeForNullDefaultAnnotation() out of BinaryTypeBinding. Isn't the null default one of the parts that should be cached by cachePartsFrom?
(c) Luckily we don't need to handle defaults for local types, as these cannot be referenced from outside.
I couldn't check the test, since the jar is not in the patch ;)
(In reply to comment #7) > (In reply to comment #6) > > I'm at a loss to understand how to handle this situation. Stephan, do you have > > any ideas? > Sorry for bringing this up again. This has been discussed in the past a few > times already. bug 365387 comment 53 has the final verdict on this point.
See also bug 369079.
Created attachment 211330 jar for tests
(In reply to comment #10) > Created attachment 211330 [details] > jar for tests Has to go in /org.eclipse.jdt.core.tests.compiler/workspace/

(In reply to comment #9)
> (1) The value of CharOperation.equals(binaryBinding.sourceName(), > TypeConstants.PACKAGE_INFO_NAME) > could be cached inside scanTypeForNullDefaultAnnotation(), a nicely named local > variable would improve readability :) I agree. > (2) Thanks for handling annotations on enclosing types, which my patch missed. > However, what happens if binaryBinding.enclosingType is an > UnresolvedReferenceBinding? I'm afraid we'd need to use > binaryBinding.enclosingType() which spoils lazy resolving for projects that use > null annotations. Or is that scenario unreachable in the first place? Hmm, good point. Though given that an enclosed type will be built only after the enclosing, I don't know if an Unresolved binding can come here. How do I test this case? > (3) Why is a loop over enclosingType() needed? Can't we assume the directly > enclosing has all necessary information? I'm not sure. Yes, the loop is not required. :) > (4) Lookup of package-info inside scanTypeForNullDefaultAnnotation() can > actually be avoided if the type has a default annotation. Why not defer until > before the very final switch in this method? I agree with this too. > Some more notes which don't require any action:
> (b) I'm not sure what's the advantage of pulling the call to > scanTypeForNullDefaultAnnotation() out of BinaryTypeBinding. Isn't the null > default one of the parts that should be cached by cachePartsFrom? The advantage is that we have the binding there from which we can easily get the enclosing type.

Created attachment 211381 updated patch + tests
This is the updated patch according to above comments. Regarding the Unresolved binding issue, I don't think its possible because org.eclipse.jdt.internal.compiler.lookup.LookupEnvironment.createBinaryTypeFrom(IBinaryType, PackageBinding, boolean, AccessRestriction) is always called first for the enclosing type and then the inner types. And even when an unresolved binding is found in the cache, we don;t use that for the scanTypes... call.
Stephan, I'll release if the patch is ok with you
Created attachment 211382 updated jar for tests

(In reply to comment #12) > > (b) I'm not sure what's the advantage of pulling the call to > > scanTypeForNullDefaultAnnotation() out of BinaryTypeBinding. Isn't the null > > default one of the parts that should be cached by cachePartsFrom? > The advantage is that we have the binding there from which we can easily get > the enclosing type.
Frankly, I don't see any relevant information that would be easier available in the lookup environment than in the type. But since this was in the nit-picking category to begin with, you have my +1 for the latest patch.

(In reply to comment #15) > The closest I could come to breaking our assumption was: > [..] > So our assumption is correct: we never get a resolved inner with an unresolved > outer, but I doubt that this is fully by design. ;P Wow, this was a good experiment. So by hook or fluke, we get there safe. I've updated the tests to include this case as well. :)
Released in master via commit e77c75055c6e55ba37ac2535228b20280659d48b

Created attachment 212543 additional tests
These are the projects I used for verifying. I think they cover a few combinations not covered by the original unit tests, like default cancelation, default override using @Nullable and more complete testing of params & return. Might want to convert these into an additional JUnit on a lazy day ...
Verified for 3.8 M6 using build I20120312-1800

Created attachment 212544 additional test v2
even stronger version of the tests from comment 18

attachment.desc: Fixes for annotation on binary package
